name: Kepler-194
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-194 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-194 is a star with 0.9770000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.02 times its radius. It is located 3696.91 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-194 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-194 b

Kepler-194 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.03 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 2.09 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-194.

The mass of Kepler-194 b is 2.60 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-194 b is 1.51 that of Earth. At 2.60 Earth masses, Kepler-194 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-194 c

Kepler-194 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 17.31 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-194.

The mass of Kepler-194 c is 9.44 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-194 c is 2.59 that of Earth. At 9.44 Earth masses, Kepler-194 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-194 d

Kepler-194 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.28 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 52.81 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-194.

The mass of Kepler-194 d is 7.86 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-194 d is 2.4 that of Earth. At 7.86 Earth masses, Kepler-194 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-194, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
